title: The Singing Gate Run
description: Skarnhold holds its breath as if the entire rift-city remembered a shared inhalation from the founding night and chose to keep it. Lifts hang polite in their slots like patient stars on iron strings, the bells at the Underrun glow blue as if dusk had pooled inside them, and the city’s pulse narrows into one planned motion that feels ancient and newborn at once. Jask Lumenwright presses into your palm a folded Loom edict that is less an order than a promise signed in heat, its ash-ink warm as if a heartbeat nested in the paper. The Iron Cradle—your stitched-together hymn of gyre, coil, and pact—must take the egg on a slow river run to the Singing Gate and back, not to spirit it away, but to teach the city’s lifelines to remember motion together and abandon the tyranny of stillness that profits a few and dooms the many. On the barge, Neris Undersong stands at the helm with the confidence of a pilot who has argued with the river and learned to lose gracefully; Riven Hask guards the feather-gyre with a wrench, a snarl, and a grudging tenderness for machines that try; and Nemra Coil hums a lullaby so old that even heated glass seems to bow when it hears the tune. Emberwatch wardens line the docks without masks, faces bare not as a dare but as a promise to see and be seen, watching the crowd watch itself until nerves become discipline. The river inhales, the blue bell sings an impossible chord that tastes of copper and winter sun, and for a breath the world below the Rift opens like a second Skarnhold made of shadow, patience, and reflected vows. You steer the cradle into that chord, feel the egg’s beat steady into a rhythm the whole city can keep, and understand why the Pact of First Heat is called a pact and not a law: pacts require breath, hands, and motion, renewed every time the city dares to move as one.
objectives: Receive the Loom’s edict from Jask and brief all participating factions on roles and contingencies, honoring the Pact’s letter and the river’s temperament.
Guide the Iron Cradle barge from the Underrun Docks to the Singing Gate using the map-song and blue-bell code, never halting the cradle’s motion.
Navigate luring currents and avoid a territorial stonewhale by syncing gyre spin to the whale’s song, trusting breath and counterweight alike.
Pass through the Singing Gate during the exact bell-interval and return without stopping the cradle’s motion, keeping the egg soothed and the crew in time.
Conclude with a Quiet Pour at the docks, returning measured jugs of warm water to the Ireflow to seal the pact and share the rhythm back to the city.

dialogue.speaker: Jask Lumenwright
dialogue.lines: There is no omen left unread for this day, and so the Loom lays down its riddles and lifts its hands like any laborer. There is only the work, and work is how a city confesses what it believes when the bells call it to answer. You will bring the egg to the Gate and back, Coilglass, and you will not hand it to any shadow who whispers that it knows a shorter path to safety, for shortcuts carve debts that the future pays with breath. Safety is not a place; it is a practice, a cadence we must teach ourselves until even our fear keeps time with us. Take this edict, not as permission but as a promise that the Loom will hold the chorus steady while you conduct the run. Brief the Chainwrights so their counterweights move in sympathy, the River Covenant so their bells speak plainly, the Orphans so their songs do not pull you into zeal, and the Emberwatch so order does not mistake courage for riot. If any guild asks why the city must move for an egg no one has seen, tell them that stillness is the only theft that can steal from a future we have not yet met. Return with a rhythm the city can keep, and I will spend every last ember thread we have to make sure it is never forgotten.

dialogue.speaker: Riven Hask
dialogue.lines: If anything tries to wedge a promise between our teeth, I will smash it with this wrench and write the bill in my own blood, but I’d prefer to draft the invoice in grease and laughter when we’re home. You keep the spin true, Coilglass, because the gyre is a jealous little god and it believes only in the hands it knows. I will keep fools from touching it because they think touching is the same as helping, and I will teach any saboteur the old Chainquarter lesson that meddling is an unpaid apprenticeship in pain. Listen, I don’t sing and I don’t augur, but I know when a machine goes from working to wanting, and right now this cradle wants to be brave, which is rare metal and rarer men. If the whale sings, I will count with the bolts, if the bells miss a beat I will hammer one in, and if the city gasps, I will breathe for it until my arms refuse the order. You get us through the chord and back, and I’ll finally admit that your Loom talk has more steel in it than I said aloud in the tavern.

dialogue.speaker: Neris Undersong
dialogue.lines: Listen to the river, all of you, and especially you who are brave enough to think you can steer it. It does not care what you call yourself or what your ledger declares; it erases titles with the same soft insistence it uses to round stones. It does not care what your ideology writes on paper, because rivers read nothing but weight and timing and whether minds can learn to be as patient as water in a tight place. It cares that you put your weight where the current wants it and take it away when it grows bored, and if you do that faithfully the river will let you pretend you guided it. I will ring the bell when it is time to forget our weight together, and I will lash my pride to the mast so the Gate’s shadow does not lure me into cutting a corner where corners do not exist. When the stonewhale rises, do not fear the draft; fear your certainty, and trade it for listening as if your mother whispered your true name from inside the current. Pilot’s word: we go in as one oar, one breath, one hull, and we come back the same shape, only warmer.

dialogue.speaker: Nemra Coil
dialogue.lines: Breathe with me, little one, and let the glass remember it was once sand kissed by dragons. Not you, Neris, though I see your shoulders tight as clenched tongs; I speak to the one in the glass, to the heat we swaddled in motion and promise. You have slept under our chains and our quarrels and our pride for so long that the city forgot it was holding you, and I am here to remind our hands how to cradle without clenching. Wake just enough to hear us count, and when we falter, remind us to keep time with a soft push from within, as gentle as steam beneath a kettle lid. I will sing you the lullaby the Orphans keep for ritual nights, but I will not bind you to us with it; I will ask you to choose us because we chose to keep moving for you. If fear crowds the deck, I will scatter it with verses like bright coins, and if despair climbs the rail, I will braid it into a rope and use it to tow us home. Sleep, heartbeat; wake, city; and let the Pact be a blanket we mend together instead of an heirloom we argue over in the dark.

dialogue.speaker: Harbormother Leth Oar
dialogue.lines: Blue-bell intervals are not poetry, they are math that sings, and if you treat them like mood you will clip the Gate’s edge and shave your luck to bone. The Covenant stands with you because a river that is taxed into stasis is a river that forgets its own name, and we pilot names for a living. My wardens will clear the choke-points, my barges will hold back their greed to give you wide water, and my bells will speak plain even if the Loom’s omens make the guildmasters grind their teeth. If the Veil and Ledger try to sell you a shadow window, remember that counterfeit timing is a trap with polite manners. Do not stop the cradle’s motion, not even to bow to a cheering crowd or curse a heckler; the first time you pause for pride, the current learns you’re a pedestal and not a pilot. When you return, I will pour the first jug at the Quiet Pour with you, and together we will teach the river to remember this day as a kindness paid back with current.

dialogue.speaker: Commander Thane Brask
dialogue.lines: I have my wardens unmasked so the city remembers we breathe the same hot air and cough the same slag dust when things go wrong. Emberwatch will not turn this into a parade and it will not turn into a riot if I can help it, because both chew through discipline in different costumes. You will hear rumors that I want your cradle seized and inventoried; the truth is I want it moving where people can see itself moving, because hidden machines breed myths, and myths breed fires that water cannot quench. If any officer tries to halt you without my writ, they are a fool or someone else’s debt, and I own neither. Keep your crew tight, keep your crowds at arm’s length without contempt, and if trouble throws a rope over your gyre, cut it—my report can absorb the scandal, but your cradle cannot absorb a single stop. Bring it back and you will find Emberwatch stubborn in your defense the next time the bells go blue and half the city wants to argue instead of work.

dialogue.speaker: Ash-Priest Saro
dialogue.lines: The Pact of First Heat is not a story we tell to make children afraid of breaking promises; it is the recipe of the city’s bread and the rhythm of its lungs. Aelmyr burned so that we would remember warmth is not theft when shared, and it curdles into poison when hoarded under sigils and locks. You take this egg to the Gate and back not as smugglers but as midwives of a memory the Rift can live by, and if you are faithful, the Orphans will speak your names during Coilnight with ash on our tongues and gratitude in our bones. Beware those who would ask for a glimpse, a touch, a proof, for proof is the little brother of hunger and it will eat a future whole. I bless your motion and I curse any stillness that would claim to be prudence when it is only fear; let that curse shatter on the stones of any who scheme to slow you. When you return, I will set seven emberstones along the Processional and hum the old beat, and even the vents will nod to the rhythm you have carried.

dialogue.speaker: Neris Coilglass
dialogue.lines: The chord tastes like winter sunlight on copper, and the gyre feels lighter than it has any right to be, as if weight itself has agreed to a truce with us for an afternoon. We have tied our doubts into neat knots and left them on the dock, and we have braided our separate loyalties into a rope strong enough to tow a city across a breath. If I die today, it will not be from fear; it will be from too much honesty told too quickly to a river that prefers patient truths, but I do not intend to die and the river does not intend to make me a liar. Hold fast, keep count, and let the song be the boss we all obey, because a good song is the only tyrant this city deserves. We are threaded to a future that prefers motion to monuments, and we will return with a rhythm so simple that even our enemies will hum it without noticing. If anyone asks what we carried, tell them we carried a promise from one side of a breath to the other and never set it down.

choices.title: Open the Weave: Hold a public briefing beneath the blue bells
choices.text: You climb a crate on the Underrun quay and call the Chainwrights, the River Covenant, the Orphans, the Emberwatch, and the terrace folk forward until the docks are a stepped theater of breath and expectation. You read Jask’s edict aloud and explain the path in clear bells and clearer words, drawing the map-song in the air with ash-ink until even skeptics nod at the simplicity of the counts. You name fail-points and contingencies without flinching, promise no heroics, and ask for only one miracle: coordination born of trust for an hour. You invite questions and answer even the crooked ones with patience, refusing to trade certainty for applause. When you finish, you ask the crowd to practice breathing together, and the blue lights throb in time as if the city’s ribs had learned to listen.
choices.outcome: The Emberwatch stands down its edgiest wardens because transparency is a solvent for paranoia, and Commander Brask lends you a squad to keep aisleways open without theater. The River Covenant buys into your counts fully, assigning their best bellkeepers to shadow your intervals and discouraging any blue-bell black auctions that might muddy the code. The Orphans hum along with Nemra and pledge to disperse any zeal that tightens the crowd, choosing service over spectacle. The Salt Charter grumbles at the coin they cannot skim in the confusion, but Matron Talan Sers admits aloud that good timing is cheaper than riots, and she pockets her ledgers with frosty dignity. The Veil and Ledger note your refusal to bargain in dusk, which earns you a momentary respite from their arithmetic but paints a target on the back of your schedules; for now, the barge launches cleaner, the bells sound brighter, and the city’s first lesson in shared breath takes root.

choices.title: Quiet Slip: Depart under hush at false dawn
choices.text: You decline speeches and lantern theater, choosing instead a timing window when the vents sigh warm and the dock traders haven’t yet tallied their first quarrel. You signal the Covenant with a hand of silent signs and let the blue bells murmur as if in sleep, pulling the cradle into the current with oars that do not splash and orders that are less than whispers. You brief the crew in the dark with breath against metal so your words climb through the hull and carry without echo. You ask Nemra to hum low and steady so the lullaby is a contrail and not a banner, and you tell Riven to keep the wrench under a canvas like a prayer too honest to show. The city wakes to find you already a curve downriver, and gossip has to jog to keep up with you instead of running ahead to lay snare-lines.
choices.outcome: You avoid the first round of grandstanding saboteurs and the petty theatrics that so often gum the teeth of good machinery, buying your gyre three untroubled intervals. Emberwatch, caught between gratitude and bruised pride, shadows you with a lean patrol that keeps distance and writes notes, promising questions later when the city is not listening. The Orphans worry at being shut out of the opening vow, but Nemra bridges the slight with a whispered hymn that threads back through their ranks like a promise quietly honored, and they fall into supportive silence. The River Covenant bellkeepers grumble at the lost chance to demonstrate ritual precision, and for a moment their counting lags your hull; you correct with a firm command and a gesture toward their pride, and the intervals snap tight again. The Veil and Ledger cannot find a purchase in the calm, so they take notes instead of taxes, which is its own kind of debt; you pay it later with a glare and an inconvenient truth that costs you a drink but not your schedule.

choices.title: Deep Counter: Tune the gyre to the stonewhale’s song
choices.text: When the river deepens to a bass thrum and the current fattens with heat, you taste the mineral sweetness that means a stonewhale is near and not in a mood to share lanes. You signal the crew to soften every sound until even the oarlocks seem to hold their breath, and you spin the feather-gyre with the calibrator against your palm, feeling for the faultlines in the song. Nemra lowers the lullaby to a thread and lets the whale’s call drape over it like velvet, and Neris Undersong steadies the helm with hands that know reverence and refusal at once. You count aloud for the crew, turning your voice into a metronome that asks the whale, politely and persistently, to consider you part of the river’s machinery instead of an insult to it. When the whale rises beneath you like a continent considering its options, you let the gyre’s pitch tilt a hair toward its pulse, meeting power with respect and giving way without surrender.
choices.outcome: The stonewhale hums an answering bar that rattles the glass ribs of the cradle without malice, and the river folds around you as if a muscle decided to carry a bead of light instead of squeezing it dry. Your crew feels the pressure and learns the art of leaning without flinching, a lesson that will live in their bones longer than any speech. Neris Undersong steals a grin like a stolen sun and tips the helm one notch to the good, buying you a cushion that makes the Singing Gate’s timing window larger by a heartbeat. You lose a slice of schedule that will make certain Chainwrights mutter about softness, but you gain a call-and-response that every bellkeeper on the Underrun hears and memorizes for the next surge season. The Orphans claim the whale’s acceptance as a sign that the egg is pleased and the Pact is honored, and even Emberwatch files a report that uses the word ‘grace’ without sarcasm; the city has learned a deeper counterweight, and you carry that new rhythm home.

choices.title: Shadow Ledger: Let the Veil broker a clean corridor
choices.text: Auditor Nightleaf arrives with figures that look like penance and a smile like a lock oiled by confession, offering you a corridor of uninspected minutes between choke-points. The pitch is simple: fewer eyes, no rival bells, and staggered docks that seem to move aside before you like courtiers with good manners and worse intentions. You know the Veil never clears space without filling it with obligation, and you say so, but you also know that clean time is the most expensive cargo in the city. You set terms aloud so everyone can hear: no manifest sleights, no secret passengers, no diversion of praise or blame, and no hand on the gyre that isn’t yours. Nightleaf bows as if you have already agreed and waits with a ledger that smells faintly of smokeherb and solemn regret.
choices.outcome: The corridor opens like a zipper in a crowded market, and for three stretches the river is yours in a way that makes the crew superstitious about speaking above a murmur. The price comes due immediately in reputation, because favors ink themselves in rumors faster than in books; Emberwatch watches harder, the River Covenant winces at the optics, and the Orphans sing a verse about deals struck in dusk. Yet the Veil keeps their word with the precision of thieves who know the law better than the law does, and not a single rival bell rings out of turn. At the Gate, you feel the interval open as cleanly as a cut made by a sharp blade, and you pass through with the egg’s beat steady and high, a proof the Veil will claim a share of even if they never touch the cradle. On your return, Nightleaf asks for nothing more than a memory of how the chord tasted; you give them a look that says you remember your mother’s face less clearly than you remember that taste, and for once they shut the book without a figure added.

rewards.description: Citywide recognition of the Iron Cradle protocol, spoken from docks to terraces as the right way to keep pact-heat in motion when fear or famine threatens.
Standing access to coordinated lift and dock windows during crises, with bells and chains held for you as if the city had learned your count by heart.
Harmonized with Loom, Chainwrights, River Covenant, and Orphans, your name carried in good breath among factions that rarely share one.
Ceremonial brass-and-copper ring, stamped at the Quiet Pour, signifying Keeper of Motion and warm to the touch whenever a bell rings true.
